articles.headline: For Mnuchin, a Lesson in How Words Can Move Markets
articles.snippet: Steven Mnuchin, whose apparently offhand remark on the dollar caused a tumble, joins many Treasury secretaries whose words have been given more meaning than intended.
articles.abstract: Steven Mnuchin, whose apparently offhand remark on the dollar caused a tumble, joins many Treasury secretaries whose words have been given more meaning than intended.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — His name now appears on the dollar bill. But that does not mean it is safe for him to actually talk about the dollar.

articles.headline: Trump Immigration Plan Demands Tough Concessions From Democrats
articles.snippet: If Democrats want relief for young unauthorized immigrants, they would have to accept a border wall and restrictions on low-skilled immigrants joining their families in America.
articles.abstract: If Democrats want relief for young unauthorized immigrants, they would have to accept a border wall and restrictions on low-skilled immigrants joining their families in America.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump proposed legislation on Thursday that would provide a path to citizenship for as many as 1.8 million young undocumented immigrants in exchange for an end to decades of family-based migration policies, a costly border wall and a vast crackdown on other immigrants living in the country illegally.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Is Indianapolis Cool Enough for Amazon? It Just Might Be
articles.snippet: The Midwest capital city would seem to be a long shot for Amazon’s new headquarters, but its low costs and business-friendly climate might help its chances.
articles.abstract: The Midwest capital city would seem to be a long shot for Amazon’s new headquarters, but its low costs and business-friendly climate might help its chances.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among Amazon’s 20 finalist cities for its coveted second headquarters are several that would have to be called long shots: Columbus, Ohio, Nashville and Miami, to name three.

articles.headline: 10 Monkeys and a Beetle: Inside VW’s Campaign for ‘Clean Diesel’
articles.snippet: An experiment that produced false data sheds light on how German automakers financed scientific research to promote their political agenda.
articles.abstract: An experiment that produced false data sheds light on how German automakers financed scientific research to promote their political agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — In 2014, as evidence mounted about the harmful effects of diesel exhaust on human health, scientists in an Albuquerque laboratory conducted an unusual experiment: Ten monkeys squatted in airtight chambers, watching cartoons for entertainment as they inhaled fumes from a diesel Volkswagen Beetle.

articles.headline: Trump and Davos: Not Exactly Best Friends, but Not Enemies Either
articles.snippet: Last year, the chieftains at Davos were panicked at the thought of Trump. This year, they welcomed him with somewhat open arms.
articles.abstract: Last year, the chieftains at Davos were panicked at the thought of Trump. This year, they welcomed him with somewhat open arms.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — When President Trump arrived on Thursday at the conference center where the world’s financial and political elite have been meeting, onlookers crowded a balcony and craned their heads to see the leader who has challenged the very international order that Davos represents. At first, it was quiet. Then someone called out a question.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Peter S. Goodman

articles.headline: Why Is Pay Lagging? Maybe Too Many Mergers in the Heartland
articles.snippet: Consolidation is often seen as a consumer problem. But it may also reduce competition for workers, especially outside big cities, holding down wages.
articles.abstract: Consolidation is often seen as a consumer problem. But it may also reduce competition for workers, especially outside big cities, holding down wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN, Wis. — For as long as he can remember, the only thing Matt Gies really wanted to do for a living was repair farm equipment.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Trump Appointee Is Trying to Squelch Us, Labor Board Staff Says
articles.snippet: The civil servants who handle most labor-relations cases — a group seen by critics as anti-employer — have expressed alarm over a proposal to demote them.
articles.abstract: The civil servants who handle most labor-relations cases — a group seen by critics as anti-employer — have expressed alarm over a proposal to demote them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration’s efforts to reverse the direction of federal labor policy appear to have accelerated with a proposal to demote the senior civil servants who resolve most labor cases.

articles.headline: Trump Ordered Mueller Fired, but Backed Off When White House Counsel Threatened to Quit
articles.snippet: The president ordered the firing last June as he first learned that the special counsel might be investigating whether he had obstructed justice.
articles.abstract: The president ordered the firing last June as he first learned that the special counsel might be investigating whether he had obstructed justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump ordered the firing last June of Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel overseeing the Russia investigation, according to four people told of the matter, but ultimately backed down after the White House counsel threatened to resign rather than carry out the directive.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: With Larry Nassar Sentenced, Focus Is on What Michigan State Knew
articles.snippet: Federal and state authorities began investigations of what the university knew about Dr. Nassar’s abuse while he was employed there for two decades.
articles.abstract: Federal and state authorities began investigations of what the university knew about Dr. Nassar’s abuse while he was employed there for two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michigan State University was propelled on Thursday to the center of the sexual abuse scandal involving Dr. Lawrence G. Nassar, as state and federal agencies mounted investigations demanding to know what the college knew of his behavior and when.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Anemona Hartocollis

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Grew at 2.6% Rate in Fourth Quarter
articles.snippet: Combined with a sinking jobless rate, a surging stock market and a sunny outlook, the report signaled continuing resilience.
articles.abstract: Combined with a sinking jobless rate, a surging stock market and a sunny outlook, the report signaled continuing resilience.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy finished off last year on a firm footing, and is poised for more vigorous growth in the months to come.

articles.headline: A Sober Trump Reassures the Davos Elite
articles.snippet: In a restrained speech, the president argued that his “America First” policies were consistent with the current global economic system.
articles.abstract: In a restrained speech, the president argued that his “America First” policies were consistent with the current global economic system.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — On the campaign trail, Donald J. Trump the candidate denounced what he called “the false song of globalism.” A year after taking office, President Trump came on Friday to tell the elites at Davos, who composed the song, that maybe they could still perform in harmony.
